The entrance hall to Lyssieth's palace is staggeringly opulent, and is in complete contrast to the dark, drab exterior. The floor beneath your feet is a perfectly polished expanse of clean white marble, and is adorned with a luxuriant red runner carpet which stretches off down the three corridors that are linked to each side of the hall. The walls are covered in white, wooden panelling; their decorative, intricately-carved features are painted in bright gold. Gigantic portraits of regal-looking demons and humans hang on the walls, and up above, the high ceiling is lavishly decorated in the same white-and-gold style as the rest of your surroundings.

Taking a closer look at your surroundings, you take note of the fact that there are a couple of half-demon and human maids standing to attention on opposite sides of the hall. Obviously having been trained exceptionally well, they remain completely motionless as they wait for you to leave this area.

Deciding to leave Lyssieth's palace, you exit through the same wicket gate by which you enetered, and head out over the drawbridge back into Submission. Once at the far side, Elizabeth turns to face you, and asks, [elizabeth.speech(Ah, [pc.name], did your business with Lyssieth go well?)]

[pc.speech(Yes, thank you,)] you respond, before quickly saying that you need to be on your way.

[elizabeth.speech(Very well,)] Elizabeth responds, [elizabeth.speech(If you ever need to visit Lyssieth again, you have full permission to come and go from her palace as you please.)]

Thanking the half-succubus for the information, you continue on your way into Submission, and start heading back across the huge cavern's floor...

Each corridor of Lyssieth's palace is just as ostentatiously luxurious as the next. Just like the entrance hall, the floor is of polished white marble, with a red runner carpet laid down the very centre. The walls are panelled in white and gold, and upon them hang huge portraits of demons and humans. Up above, the high ceiling is trimmed with decorative mouldings, and in even intervals, huge crystal chandeliers hang down to illuminate your surroundings.

Lining the walls, there are countless marble statues, ornate seats, and glass-fronted display cabinets. While most of these are filled with expected array of china and other miscellaneous decorative articles, there are several which house relics from Lily's museum, as well as one or two which contain extremely mundane objects from the outside world.

Just as in the rest of the palace, there's an occasional half-demon or human maid standing up against a wall, waiting for you to pass before continuing with her duties.

The corridors which branch off to the left and right of the main entrance hall are slightly narrower than the one which leads directly to Lyssieth's office. There are also far fewer ornamental objects lining the walls, and, most notably of all, there are a series of narrow, arrow-slit-like windows set into one side. Looking out of one of these, you see Elizabeth and her troops standing guard on the other side of the drawbridge. Other than those royal guard, however, there's nothing really much to see from here, and so you continue on your way forwards.

Just as in the rest of the palace, there's an occasional half-demon or human maid standing up against a wall, waiting for you to pass before continuing with her duties.

The rooms on this floor of Lyssieth's palace all have their doors wide open, and, peering inside, you see that each one appears to be a well-furnished drawing room. Plush sofas, extravagantly-carved coffee tables, and even the odd piano can be found in these places. In a similar fashion to the palace's corridors, portraits of demons and humans line the walls, while underfoot, luxuriant carpeting provides a comfortable surface upon which to stand.

Within each of these room, one or two maids are standing to attention, dutifully waiting to serve any of Lyssieth's guests.

In each wing of the palace, there is a long, extravagantly-furnished dining hall, in which you assume Lyssieth must entertain her guests. The rich mahogany table that runs down the middle of the room must be at least twenty metres in length, and to either side sit a huge number of regal-looking chairs.

With the exception of two half-demon maids standing to attention on either side of the room, the hall is completely unoccupied.

A huge, red-carpeted staircase, which reminds you very much of the one in Lilaya's home, leads to the upper floors of the palace. As you approach it, a half-demon maid steps forwards to block your passage. With a respectful curtsy, she says, [genericFemale.speech(A thousand apologies, [pc.sir], but I regret to inform you that we've been instructed not to allow any guests into the upper floors.)]

With no business being up there anyway, you step back and wonder where to head to next...
